text.headline: Ancient and Modern Social Developments
text.text: The period from 5000 BCE to 500 CE, focusing on the foundations of gender norms in ancient civilizations.

text.headline: Mesopotamia
text.text: Gender roles were entrenched in Mesopotamia, with women primarily managing households and men dominating public spheres (Adana et al., 2011).

text.headline: Egypt
text.text: Egyptian society had more fluid gender roles, with women holding significant positions but still primarily responsible for domestic duties (Adana et al., 2011; Steinmetz et al., 2014).

text.headline: Greece
text.text: In Greece, gender roles were strict, especially in Athens, with women confined to domestic tasks and men active in public life (Steinmetz et al., 2014).

text.headline: Rome
text.text: Roman gender norms were strict, but women of higher status could hold unique religious roles, granting some autonomy (Adana et al., 2011; Steinmetz et al., 2014).

text.headline: Ancient Civilizations: Foundations of Gender Norms
text.text: In ancient Mesopotamia, Egypt, Greece, and Rome, gender roles were rigidly defined and deeply rooted in societal structures. Men typically engaged in public life, politics, and warfare, while women were confined to domestic roles. These early civilizations laid the groundwork for contemporary gender norms through their legal systems and cultural practices, and ensured that women remained subordinate, impacting their social and economic status. While these historical analyses provide a foundation, it is crucial to question the extent to which these rigid structures were universally enforced. Evidence suggests that in less documented areas and among lower classes, women might have had more varied roles, often participating in local trade and agricultural activities which were less controlled by formal legal codes. For example, in ancient Egypt, women of lower classes often worked alongside men in the fields and engaged in trade (Lesko, 1991). This indicates that economic necessity could override formal gender norms, leading to more fluid gender roles in practice.

text.headline: Early Middle Ages
text.text: Gender norms were heavily influenced by religious doctrines, with women confined to domestic roles and men dominating public spheres (DeWitte, 2010).

text.headline: High Middle Ages
text.text: The Church further entrenched gender roles, emphasizing women's subordination and their roles as obedient wives and nurturing mothers (Morgan, 1987).

text.headline: Late Middle Ages
text.text: Socioeconomic changes slightly broadened women's roles, but traditional views persisted, influenced by the Church and societal norms (Aidala, 1985).

text.headline: Renaissance Era
text.text: Despite intellectual advances, gender roles were largely patriarchal, with women confined to domestic spheres (Aidala, 1985).

text.headline: Enlightenment Era
text.text: The Enlightenment challenged traditional gender roles, advocating for women's rights and education, but practical changes were slow (De Lemus et al., 2018).

text.headline: Early Industrial Revolution
text.text: Industrialization reinforced the male breadwinner model, with men in factory jobs and women managing domestic responsibilities (De Macêdo, 1996; Cooke, 2004).

text.headline: Mid Industrial Revolution
text.text: Women’s participation in the workforce began challenging traditional gender roles, though often in low-paid, menial jobs (Semyonov, 1980).

text.headline: Late Industrial Revolution
text.text: Increased literacy and economic necessity led to gradual acceptance of women's rights and integration into the workforce (Miller, 1984; Alwin et al., 1992).

text.headline: Pre-World War I Era
text.text: Gender norms were rigid, with men as breadwinners and women as caregivers, with limited workforce opportunities for women (Cott, 1987).

text.headline: Post-Industrial Revolution
text.text: Women’s workforce participation reshaped gender norms, initiating social reforms aimed at gender equality (Loscocco & Spitze, 1990).

text.headline: World War I and Interwar Period
text.text: Women took on traditionally male roles during wartime labour shortages, temporarily disrupting traditional gender norms (Smith, 2000).

text.headline: World War II Era
text.text: Women’s increased workforce participation during WWII significantly altered perceptions of gender roles, though post-war pressures to return to domesticity persisted (Hartmann, 1982).

text.headline: Post-World War II
text.text: Post-war, societal push for traditional gender roles clashed with women’s demonstrated capabilities in various fields, leading to gradual shifts toward gender equality (Chafe, 1972).

text.headline: Post-WWII Gender Norms and Social Changes
text.text: Post-WWII saw reinforced traditional gender roles with men as breadwinners and women as homemakers, despite women’s significant wartime contributions (May, 1988).

text.headline: The Rise of Feminist Movements
text.text: The 1960s and 1970s feminist movement challenged traditional gender roles, advocating for workplace equality, reproductive rights, and legal reforms (Freeman, 1975).

text.headline: Gender equality: Progress and Resistance
text.text: Significant progress in gender equality occurred, but resistance persisted, particularly in occupational segregation and the gender pay gap (England et al., 2020).

text.headline: Institutional and Cultural Shifts
text.text: Policies promoting equal opportunity increased women's representation in professional roles, but deeper cultural changes were needed to eradicate ingrained norms (England et al., 2020).

text.headline: Persistent Challenges
text.text: Educational and employment gains for women highlighted the need for further reforms to address pay gaps and occupational segregation (England et al., 2020).

text.headline: Early 21st Century
text.text: Educational and employment gains for women highlighted the need for further reforms to address pay gaps and occupational segregation (England et al., 2020).

text.headline: Mid-21st Century
text.text: Despite progress, significant disparities in political representation and occupational segregation remained, with women facing gender bias in leadership roles and online interactions (McGregor & Mourão, 2016; Koc-Michalska et al., 2021).

text.headline: Late-21st Century
text.text: COVID-19 underscored women's essential roles in paid and unpaid labour, leading to calls for greater support for caregivers and flexible work arrangements to promote gender equality (England et al., 2020).
